abstract.p: Letter from Con Ed vice president Frances A Resheske disputes August 8 editorial condemning steep rise in electric rates

block.p: Last year, under New York State's deregulation, Consolidated Edison sold its in-city electric generating plants. ''Those Shocking Electric Bills'' (editorial, Aug. 8) calls for Con Edison to give consumers ''a fair share of the money'' from the power plant sales.

Last year, under New York State's deregulation, Consolidated Edison sold its in-city electric generating plants. ''Those Shocking Electric Bills'' (editorial, Aug. 8) calls for Con Edison to give consumers ''a fair share of the money'' from the power plant sales.

The gross profit from our plant sales was $836 million. Of this, more than $500 million was paid in federal taxes and more than $12 million was paid in state and city taxes. The remainder was set aside to benefit customers. The New York State Public Service Commission determines how this money will be used; $100 million has already been allocated for long- and short-term rate reduction. The commission will decide how the remaining $200 million will be delivered to customers.
Con Edison has not and will not receive any profits from the plant sales.
FRANCES A. RESHESKE Vice President, Public Affairs Con Edison New York, Aug. 10, 2000
